Jan 14

Because I couldn’t stop for Death

PROLOGUE

This story of mine is inspired by Emily Dickinson’s poem,’ Because I couldn’t stop for Death.’ A reader may find it interesting to read before viewing my twisted version…

Because I could not stop for Death -
He kindly stopped for me -
The Carriage held but just Ourselves -
And Immortality.

We slowly drove — He knew no haste
And I had put away
My labor and my leisure too,
For His Civility -

We passed the School, where Children strove
At Recess — in the Ring -
We passed the Fields of Gazing Grain -
We passed the Setting Sun -

Or rather — He passed Us -
The Dews drew quivering and Chill -
For only Gossamer, my Gown -
My Tippet — only Tulle -

We paused before a House that seemed
A Swelling of the Ground -
The Roof was scarcely visible -
The Cornice — in the Ground -

Since then — ’tis Centuries — and yet
Feels shorter than the Day
I first surmised the Horses’ Heads
Were toward Eternity -

- Emily Dickinson

× — × — × — × — × — × — × — × — × — × — × — × — × — × — × — × — ×

I gaze at a falling, or maybe drowning snowflake. It flutters about in the open, wintry air, looking for its paramour. Through my hazy car window, I can’t help but stare at this solitary flake, pitying its incomplete companionship. But, who am I to judge nature, when I myself am broken? This twinkling, sparkling Christmas Eve only scorns me, reminding me of a dark, haunted time. Oh, if only I could sit back and fall asleep, asleep to an endless, dreamless night. If only I could break free from this suffocating cage of responsibilities, and absorb the Christmas spirit, to store forever. My forlorn spell of thoughts shatters as my seat starts vibrating, indicating that my phone is ringing. I gingerly cradle the phone in my bruised hand- actually, my mutilated hand. Note: the aftermath of your employer forcing your hand into an oven, is not to go unnoticed.

Seeing that my precious daughter was calling me, I quickly answer.

Her voice rings through my mind, clearing my blurred thoughts, like the sunshine after a storm. ‘Mom, where are you? Come home, quick! I can’t find my only pair of socks and its freezing in here- It’s so scary without you!’, she whines. My racing emotions narrow down to ones of anxiety and desperation. ‘I’m coming darling, just hold on, I’m coming,’ I cry out. Fumbling with the speaker button, I tell her to keep talking, reminding her that I’m on my way. Starting my car, I barely see the distant headlights of an incoming vehicle. As my daughter’s voice echoes in my ears, I raise my eyes to the windshield. A glistening pair of lights blinds my sight. I raise my hand to block the blaze and suddenly I am jolted forward.

A word of advice. Never, never, accidently park on the wrong side of the road at night. More than the excruciating pain, more than the initial shock, the despairing voice of my daughter shook me. One howl, in response to my screams, ‘Mom!!’, then the darkness enveloped me. I was sinking into the depths of my agony and hopeless attempts to grasp on to memories. My eyes closed, my thoughts spiralling into an obscure whirlpool…

His whisper wakes me up. It startles me, never had a man been so close to me, whispering in my ear. ‘Isabelle.’ ‘Wake up.’ ‘Isabelle.’

His voice is like a blanket of honey, so sweet, so thick, so foreign. I jerk away, and he leans back, with a comforting smile on his handsome features. Handsome? Get a grip Isabelle. Where are you? Suddenly alert, I scan my surroundings with inexplicable surprise. I am perched on a wooden seat in the back of an elegant carriage. The carriage is glimmering gold, adorned with silver jewels. Two gallant, dark maned horses are tied to the front with a sturdy, glazed rope. As they turn their faces to me, their fiery, red eyes halt me in my appreciation. It makes me feel tiny inside, as if they could pounce on me any moment. The wheels of the carriage have eight sharp hazel, cunning spokes, poised in position to strike the innocent ground.

The man is smiling, whether in pity or joy, I can’t tell. He’s wearing a pitch black suit, and is quite fair. Our carriage rests on a muddy track surrounded by lush, green fields. To my far left, a lone banyan tree stands tall, its branches hanging with a slight sense of flair. The man suddenly turns around, and whips the ropes onto the horses. The carriage tentatively starts moving, and then we’re off onto this endless track of ambiguity.

My thoughts are spinning, confusion setting in. Amidst my attempts to remember, I can feel a void in my memories. Something tugs on to me, but I just don’t know who I am and how I landed here. I wear a white, knee-length dress, and someone has braided my hair. The man seems to emit an aura of kindness, so I tap on his shoulders and ask, ‘Who am I? Who are you? Where are we going?’, in a rushed flow of speech. He politely says, ‘Who am I? I’, just a fragment of your imagination. Who are you? You, you are Isabelle. We’re going where you’ve always wanted to.’ With this elegantly yet cryptically said, he rides on. Fragment of my imagination? Yes, this is the only thing that strikes a bell with reality right now. Imagination is the right word. I sit back, and decide to relax, feeling that this man’s courtesy and honesty is earnest enough for me to feel safe and secure. I decide to see what happens, and snap out of it as soon as the atmosphere turns unsettling.

Where did I always want to go? A sliver of a memory shudders through me. I remember. I have a daughter. I’ve always wanted to go to heaven, and sleep an endless sleep. Is that where we’re going? Paradise? Then who’s taking me there? Death? No, this polite man couldn’t be Death. Although, the idea of Death has always been like a diamond to me, shining and glamorous. Yes, this ride could be it… No, it’s just too good, too evil to be true. I can’t succumb to my far-fetched thoughts.

As we slowly advance, I realise I hadn’t paid attention to the dark evening sky. It fades now, dissolving into a tangerine sunrise. It’s as if the sun is greeting me. Neither do I pass it, nor does it pass me. The sun gracefully twinkles at me, as if it knows the destination of my journey. Abruptly, the man turns and says, ‘We’re almost there. Immortality awaits.’ So it’s true. This is Death. People always consider Death as a dark, cruel devil, the one who buries you after sunset. In my case, Death is civil. We greet the light, instead of bidding it a farewell. I guess my deep desire for this phase we call ‘mortality’ changed my path. Who knows? Someone must be watching me from above…

We approach a castle, a grandiose castle, a regal castle. Its immense magnificence snaps me out of my daze. A castle of my dreams… Dreams? Snap out Isabelle! It’s like Disney’s golden tower, its spike rising to the heights of glory… What have I done to deserve this majesty? Who decides the way the cookie crumbles? Whoever does and how, I honestly just want to bask in its warmth right now. We cruise to the entrance, over a polished, smooth road. The man, or Death, I believe, charmingly climbs out and extends a gentle hand to me for stepping out of the carriage. I can’t imagine how I must look to him. Awed? Uncertain? Fearful? It’s all brewing together in here. But, if this is Death, this must be his everyday job. Maybe, he doesn’t care. Maybe, I’m just another boring face. Bored or not, he certainly seems pleased with my silence. I guess I’m too stunned to reveal myself.

We glide into the castle, the plush doors to huge for me to keenly observe. Despite the castle’s elaborate embellishment on its exterior, from the inside it’s a stark peach hall. The only gems in the football-field wide room are 13 diamond thrones. They sparkle so brightly, momentarily making me look away. In that precious moment, the third throne on my far left is filled. A bronze-skinned, loin clothed man sits there with poise. He could be 9 feet fall, maybe even more. I feel inferior, healed and cheerful all at once in his presence. He wears a glowing laurel wreath. Could it be? I always took interest in Greek myths, and if I was right, this was the Greek God, Apollo. I’ve read about him as the one who heals, prophesies, purifies and celebrates music. He catches my gaze and says in a booming but melodious voice, ‘My dear, come hither.’ As if in a trance, I move towards him, the whole time Death holding my hand and coming along with me.

Apollo, can I even call him Apollo? He, yes, He sounds more respectful. He says,‘ Isabelle, I’ve come to offer you a choice.’ I’m too bewitched to respond. ‘Your life on Earth has been a significant interest of mine. Especially your ardent desire for death.’

Me interesting? Until now, I thought I was alone and no-one cared. Except Death, of course.

‘I offer you two roadways of destiny. I give you the right to choose, may it be a selfish or selfless decision, it is yours. On one hand, is the gateway to Idris, Heaven’s most luxurious city. On the other, is the journey back towards your daughter, who longs for your presence.’

I’m aghast. How can I choose between my deepest desire and my deepest love? Why give me such a choice? Who am I to choose? This is it though. The moment of truth. Who do I love more, myself or her? I owe it to my daughter. I owe her a mother, a bright future. But, I owe myself a break too. I need to be happy too. Isn’t my daughter joy enough to behold? Secretly, I know she’s isn’t. I need more. But she does too…

I’ve made my choice. Death lets go of my hand, maybe sensing my decision. With a surprisingly strong voice, I say, ‘My Lord, I ask for a favour, a promise with my choice…’

In the end, Apollo, or He, agreed. He stood, and ordered me to kneel. I bowed, and he placed his laurel wreath on me. Everything felt clear then, no more looming storms, no more distant worries. I rose with a renewed immortal soul, and walked with courage, with satisfaction to a glimmering portal to Idris. Had I abandoned a loved one? No. My little angel, was to be guarded by one of Heaven’s angels. A promise sealed by His oath. She would not be touched by Death, until the time would come. Some say ‘the time’ could mean any phase of life, when fate decides to arrive. To me, ‘the time’ would be when my daughter would finally attain satisfaction, and fulfill her purpose.

And I? I would finally be free.

EPILOGUE

Because I couldn’t stop for Death,

He kindly stopped for me.

With no haste, We rode on,

To a bedazzling, glittering castle,

where a trap awaited me.

Love for one, or love for myself,

I had to choose.

I had lost the will to love others,

But was promised Her comfort.

Death stepped back,

I had arrived,

Immortality, or peace at last…
